claim: A positive ELISA test confirms HIV infection

supporting.text: A positive ELISA test can produce false positives due to cross-reactivity with other antibodies, such as those from autoimmune diseases.

attacks.text: A positive ELISA test can produce false positives due to cross-reactivity with other antibodies, such as those from autoimmune diseases.
The ELISA test is highly sensitive and specific for HIV, with false positives being rare in practice.
Confirmatory tests like the Western blot are used after a positive ELISA to rule out false positives.
Autoimmune diseases that cause cross-reactivity are uncommon compared to the prevalence of HIV testing.
Even with cross-reactivity, the combination of ELISA and confirmatory tests minimizes the risk of false positives.

supporting.text: The ELISA test is a screening tool, and confirmatory tests like Western blot or PCR are required to definitively diagnose HIV infection.

attacks.text: The ELISA test is a screening tool, and confirmatory tests like Western blot or PCR are required to definitively diagnose HIV infection.
In many cases, a positive ELISA test is highly indicative of HIV infection, especially in high-prevalence populations.
Even in high-prevalence populations, false positives can occur due to cross-reactivity with other antibodies, necessitating confirmatory testing.
Some healthcare settings with limited resources rely on multiple ELISA tests as a proxy for confirmation due to lack of access to Western blot or PCR.
Relying solely on ELISA tests increases the risk of misdiagnosis and associated psychological or social harm, even in resource-limited settings.

supporting.text: Technical errors in the ELISA test procedure, such as improper handling or contamination, can lead to false-positive results.

attacks.text: Technical errors in the ELISA test procedure, such as improper handling or contamination, can lead to false-positive results.
Modern ELISA tests are highly standardized and include multiple controls to detect and prevent technical errors.
Even with controls, human error in sample handling or equipment calibration can still introduce false positives.
False positives due to technical errors are rare and usually identified through confirmatory testing like Western blot.
Confirmatory tests can also be subject to errors, delaying accurate diagnosis and treatment.

supporting.text: Recent vaccinations or infections with other viruses can sometimes trigger a positive ELISA test without actual HIV infection.

attacks.text: Recent vaccinations or infections with other viruses can sometimes trigger a positive ELISA test without actual HIV infection.
The ELISA test is highly specific to HIV antibodies, and false positives due to other infections are extremely rare in practice.
Even if false positives occur, confirmatory tests like the Western blot are always performed to rule out such cases.
Some vaccinations (e.g., flu shots) have been documented to cause cross-reactivity in ELISA tests, though still uncommon.

supporting.text: The ELISA test detects antibodies, which may take weeks to develop after infection, leading to potential false negatives or positives during the window period.

attacks.text: The ELISA test detects antibodies, which may take weeks to develop after infection, leading to potential false negatives or positives during the window period.
Modern ELISA tests have high specificity and sensitivity, minimizing false positives and negatives.
Even with high specificity, false positives can still occur due to cross-reactivity with other antibodies.
Follow-up confirmatory tests like Western blot or PCR are used to verify ELISA results, reducing diagnostic errors.
Confirmatory tests may not be immediately available in all settings, delaying definitive diagnosis.
